The Act titled "Supporting Prosecutions of International Espionage Schemes Act of 2007" revises espionage crimes in Chapter 37 of title 18, United States Code. The Act titled "Supporting Prosecutions of International Espionage Schemes Act of 2007" revises espionage crimes in Chapter 37 of title 18, United States Code. Section 791 deals with gathering or transmitting information connected with national defense, imposing severe penalties for unauthorized disclosure. Section 792 addresses the loss of such information and its consequences. Sec. 792 of the Act deals with losing information connected with national defense. It states that anyone who recklessly allows such information to be lost, stolen, or destroyed, or fails to report it promptly, may face fines or imprisonment up to 20 years. Sec. 794 of the Act outlines the forfeiture of property used in violations of the law, with the court ordering the defendant to forfeit such property to the United States. The procedures for forfeiture, seizure, and disposition of the property are governed by existing laws. The term 'foreign power' and 'information connected with the national defense' are defined in the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. The chapter does not prohibit providing information to Congress upon lawful demand. There is a 10-year statute of limitations for offenses under this chapter. The item related to chapter 37 in the table of chapters for part I of title 18, United States Code, is amended. SEC. 3. CHAPTER 115 PENALTIES.

    (a) Misprision of Treason.--Section 2382 of title 18, United States 
Code, is amended to increase the penalty from seven to 20 years.
    (b) Rebellion.--Section 2383 of title 18, United States Code, is 
amended to increase the penalty from ten to 20 years.

SEC. 4. COMPUTER ESPIONAGE. SEC. 4. COMPUTER ESPIONAGE. Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to increase penalties for computer espionage. SEC. 5 amends Section 831 of title 18, United States Code, to simplify jurisdictional language. It removes specific circumstances and broadens jurisdiction to include the United States, special maritime and territorial jurisdiction, and special aircraft jurisdiction. SEC. 6 addresses destruction or damage to nuclear facilities. Section 1366A of title 18, United States Code, addresses damage to nuclear facilities and related crimes, including causing physical damage or interruption of normal operation. Offenders face fines, imprisonment up to 30 years, or the death penalty if death results. Definitions include various types of nuclear facilities. The curr_chunk defines uranium enrichment facilities and nuclear fuel for nuclear facilities. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the United States Code. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to eliminate obsolete or superseded criminal provisions. This includes the removal of sections 91, 221, 224, 225, 226, 227, and 235, as well as subsections a. and b. of section 57, and subsection b. of section 222. Additionally, export control violations are addressed. SEC. 8. EXPORT CONTROL VIOLATIONS. Amends Chapter 27 of title 18, United States Code to include penalties for knowingly violating export control requirements under the Arms Export Control Act or the Export Administration Act of 1979. Penalties include fines up to $1,000,000 or imprisonment up to 20 years. SEC. 9. WIRETAPPING EQUIPMENT PROHIBITION CHANGE. Amends Section 2512(2)(b) of title 18, US Code to allow wiretapping equipment use under contract or authorized by. 

SEC. 10. IMPROVEMENT OF CRIMINAL CASE DISPOSITION REPORTING. SEC. 10. IMPROVEMENT OF CRIMINAL CASE DISPOSITION REPORTING. The Attorney General, in consultation with other departments, must notify officials of any criminal cases involving violations of specific acts. SEC. 11. COMPREHENSIVE IMPORT AND EXPORT CONTROL DATABASE. The Attorney General, in consultation with relevant departments, will develop a publicly accessible database for import and export control activities, including lists of products requiring licensing. SEC. 12. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO IMPROVE ENFORCEMENT OF EXPORT CONTROLS. The Attorney General, in consultation with other departments, will provide technical assistance to enhance enforcement of export control laws by training investigators and prosecutors.
